content.webTitle: Tanya Day inquest: coroner refers death in custody of Aboriginal woman for possible prosecution

fields.headline: Tanya Day inquest: coroner refers death in custody of Aboriginal woman for possible prosecution
fields.bodyText: A coroner investigating the death in custody of Aboriginal woman Tanya Day has referred the case to the department of public prosecutions to determine whether criminal negligence has occurred. Delivering her findings over livestream on Thursday, coroner Caitlin English said she made the recommendation after considering the evidence surrounding the 55-year-old Yorta Yorta woman’s death. “I believe an indictable offence may have been committed in connection to Ms Day’s death,” English said. She recommended that the Coroner’s Act be amended to give coroners more control over the investigation, conducted by police, that informs an inquest. She also recommended that a falls risk assessment be placed in the Victoria police manual’s guidelines for holding people in custody, that police training be updated with reference to the royal commission into Aboriginal deaths in custody, and that both the Victoria police and V/Line transport training manuals be subject to an independent human rights review. She also repeated an earlier recommendation, made at the first hearing of the inquest in December 2018, that the crime of public drunkenness be abolished in Victoria, to which the Andrews government has already agreed. Day died in hospital on 22 December 2017 of a brain haemorrhage sustained when she fell and hit her head in the cells of Castlemaine police station 17 days earlier. She was in the cells because she had been arrested for public drunkenness, after being removed by police from a V/Line train from Bendigo to Melbourne. English said Day’s family had asked her to consider whether the circumstances of her death amounted to negligent manslaughter. She said the medical evidence suggested Day had only a 20% chance of survival, and even then with severe disabilities once she had fallen and sustained a haematoma in the police cells, so that “any inadequacies of [police] care of Ms Day was not causative of her death”. But she said the issue of preventing her death was not limited to medical care after her fall. “Ms Day’s death was clearly preventable had she not been arrested and taken into custody. “The totality of the evidence inclines me to assenting to a belief that an indictable offence may have been committed,” English said. “And on this basis I intend to direct that the principle registrar must notify the director of public prosecutions.” The finding was delivered over livestream because of restrictions to in-person hearings due to the coronavirus. Three of Day’s four children watched the finding together in Wodonga. They had earlier called for a criminal investigation into negligence by police. The 14-day inquest into Day’s death, conducted in Melbourne last year, was the first coronial inquiry into a death in custody in Australia to consider whether systemic racism was a causative factor. English found that the police officers who took Day off the V/Line train at Castlemaine station and arrested her for public drunkenness treated her differently than they did another, non-Indigenous, severely intoxicated woman later that same day, who was driven home by police and not arrested or even fined for being drunk in public. But English said:“I am not of the view there is evidence to make a finding the differential treatment was due to Ms Day’s Aboriginality.” However, she said the decision of the train conductor, Shaun Irvine, to call police to remove Day from the train was influenced by unconscious bias. He initially described Day as “unruly” but said under cross-examination that she was not aggressive or disruptive. English said: “She was the only sleeping passenger he has ever called police to remove from the train, although he comes across three sleeping passengers a week. “The combination of this evidence suggests it is open to me to draw the inference that Mr Irvine’s decision making was influenced by unconscious bias … I find the decision to consider her unruly and to call police in preference to other options was influenced by her Aboriginality.” English said that Sergeant Edwina Neale and leading senior constable Danny Wolters, who were responsible for the police lock-up on the afternoon that Day was brought into custody, had “demonstrated a cultural complacency toward people who were drunk” and not complied with police guidelines. She said Day was “not treated with dignity and humanity” in accordance with the Victorian charter of human rights. CCTV footage showed Day fell five times while in the cell. The most significant fall occurred just before 5pm – less than an hour after she had been placed in the cell and more than three hours before police noticed a lump on her head and called an ambulance. That blow, the inquest heard, caused a significant haematoma on her left temporal lobe. The next welfare check, conducted by leading senior constable Danny Wolters at 5.35pm, consisted of him looking through the window in the cell door for about three seconds. Wolters denied a suggestion, made by lawyers for Day’s family at the inquest, that he had been “criminally negligent”. English said she did not find Wolters to be a “credible witness” and that the comments he and Neale made during the inquest – that Day was a drunk person acting as drunk people do – were concerning. “This illustrates the power of stereotype and its resistance to correction,” she said. “If the required physical checks had been conducted every 20 minutes or every 30 minutes … it may well be that Ms Day’s deterioration was detected earlier.” Day’s daughter, Apryl Day , said the finding was “bittersweet”. She is grateful the matter was referred to the DPP but frustrated that the coroner found that police had not been influenced by racism. Day said she believed police were dismissive of her mother’s condition in the police cells not just because she was drunk but because she was “an Aboriginal person drunk in a cell”. Police officers denied their conduct towards Day was influenced by her Aboriginality, and English said cross examination on this subject “yielded denials”. “Unsurprisingly, no witnesses admitted to holding racist beliefs,” English said. Day said her family was preparing for the next stage of the legal proceedings. “It’s definitely a relief that the truth of what happened to Mum has been told in the sense of acknowledging the unconscious bias from V/Line, acknowledging that Mum’s death was preventable and that she really should have never been in that cell,” Day said. “Also that we have been asking for them to refer them to the DPP so they can be held accountable, and she has heard that in our submissions and she’s going to refer them. “So we’re definitely thankful for what the process has brought. But we also acknowledge that this is just one part and now we have to gear up for another fight.”
